com.milk.uberchat.irc
Class IRCInteractor

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.milk.uberchat.irc.IRCInteractor
class IRCInteractor
extends java.lang.Object

This class does all the interaction with an IRC server. It takes input in the form of filtered messages (filtered through an IRCInputFilter) and explicit calls to do stuff. It sends stuff back to the server depending on what it's told to do, and messages etc. along to an IRCSystem depending on what gets received from the connection. BUG--when you disconnect, the interactor thread is left around. This is bad.

Author:
Dan Bornstein, danfuzz@milk.com
, Copyright 1998-1999 Dan Bornstein, all rights reserved.

doCommandTap

public void doCommandTap(java.lang.String name,
                         java.lang.String[] params,
                         int[] codes,
                         ReplyTap tap)
Send a command and tap the given reply codes, sending them to the given tap. When the tap returns true, then the tap is considered done. Alternatively, if the interactor decides the tap is done (because of an error or some other weirdness), then it sends a null to the tap and then stops sending anything else.

Parameters:
name - the command name
params - the parameters
codes - the reply codes to tap
tap - the object to send the replies to

doShutdown

public void doShutdown()
Tell the interactor to cease all activity.

threadRun

private void threadRun()
This is the main loop of the thread that deals with the connection.

beDisconnected

private void beDisconnected(java.lang.String errorMsg)
This is called when this object wants to let the system know that the connection has been or should be disconnected.

Parameters:
errorMsg - null-ok; if non-null, an error message to report to the user

receiveServerReply

private ServerReply receiveServerReply()
This will receive a message from the input, handling everything appropriately, except for ServerReply objects, which it returns without any processing. Handling appropriately includes adding Runnables to the command queue and sending the system speech (and other host activity) messages. If it receives and handles a message, it returns null.

Returns:
null-ok; the received ServerReply, if any

receiveMessage

private void receiveMessage()
This will receive a message from the input and handle it appropriately. This does everything that receiveServerReply() does, plus it will tell all ServerReplys to handle themselves.

rawSend

private void rawSend(java.lang.String str)
Send the given string to the host system.

Parameters:
str - the string to send

commandTap

private void commandTap(java.lang.String name,
                        java.lang.String[] params,
                        int[] codes,
                        ReplyTap tap)
Send a command and tap the given reply codes, sending them to the given tap. When the tap returns true, then the tap is considered done. Alternatively, if the interactor decides the tap is done (because of an error or some other weirdness), then it sends a null to the tap and then stops sending anything else.

Parameters:
name - the command name
params - the parameters
codes - the reply codes to tap
tap - the object to send the replies to
